description: Sven Halek advises the Council to permit the invisible citizens—those who disappeared from watchlists—to operate, recommending close monitoring as potential intelligence and innovation sources. He specifies Innovators should handle analysis.
IT teams detect digital activity from hundreds of missing citizens. Their scrambled, system-resistant profiles suggest deliberate coordination, prompting enhanced observation without public response.

Organized groups of previously 'invisible' citizens begin moving discreetly through Stenograd, distributing essentials to system-locked neighborhoods and bypassing BCI-secured checkpoints. Official channels remain silent, focusing on intelligence gathering.

Council receives reports of covert assemblies and coordinated disruptions orchestrated by the 'invisible.' These actions interfere with daily routines, affecting BCI-favored services and eroding Council control.

Social order deteriorates as the distinction between compliant and vanished citizens breaks down. Public trust in BCI collapses, sparking citywide calls for replacement of the system and new leadership.
